Trial_Design.evidence: An investigator-initiated, two-arm, non-blinded, multicenter, randomized, controlled trial was performed

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients older than 18 years undergoing primary knee arthroplasty. We excluded patients with an iodine allergy, previous open knee surgery, previous septic arthritis, any antibiotics taken 4 weeks before surgery, and if they were unable to understand the implications of study participation.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to operation with an antimicrobial drape (intervention group) or operation without (control group).

Objective.evidence: To study the effect of antimicrobial drapes, we used intraoperative contamination as a proxy for infection in our investigation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome measure was the difference in the proportion of contaminated patients between the two randomized groups.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to operation with an antimicrobial drape (intervention group) or operation without (control group).

Blinding.evidence: An investigator-initiated, two-arm, non-blinded, multicenter, randomized, controlled trial was performed

Number_Randomised.evidence: In all, 94% (1659 of 1769) of patients consented and were randomized to the intervention group (51%, 838 of 1659) and control group (49%, 821 of 1659), respectively.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In all, 36% (603 of 1659) of patients in the intervention group and 35% (584 of 1659) patients in the control group were available for final analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Use of iodinated drapes reduced contamination, with contamination detected in 10% (60 of 603) procedures where iodinated drapes were used compared with 15% (90 of 584) when they were not (odds ratio 0.61 [95% CI 0.43 to 0.87]; p = 0.005)
